Corresponding author $ Corresponding author Fuel cells have attracted extensive attention due to their high conversion efficiency and environmental friendliness. However, their wider application is limited by the poor activity and high cost of platinum (Pt), which is widely used as the cathode catalyst to overcome the slow kinetics associated with oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Pt-based composites with one-dimensional (1D) nanoarchitectures demonstrate great advantages towards efficient ORR catalysis. This review focuses on the recent advancements in the design and synthesis of 1D Pt-based ORR catalysts. After introducing the fundamental ORR mechanism and the advanced 1D architectures, their synthesis strategies (template-based and template-free methods) are discoursed. Subsequently, their morphology and structure optimization are highlighted, followed by the superstructure assembly using 1D Pt-based blocks. Finally, the challenges and perspectives on the synthesis innovation, structure design, physical characterization, and theoretical investigations are proposed for 1D Pt-based ORR nanocatalysts. We anticipate this study will inspire more research endeavors on efficient ORR nanocatalysts in fuel cell application. Graphical abstract This work reviews the recent developments in 1D Pt-based nanostructures, with an emphasis on the effect of their design and synthesis, physical morphologies, and chemical structures on their performance in electrocatalytic ORR in fuel cells. Keywords Fuel cells Oxygen reduction reaction Electrocatalyst Pt alloy One-dimensional 1 Introduction With the rapid population growth and abrupt consumption of traditional fossil fuels, global society needs more sustainable energy alternatives to meetup with the associated economic and industrial development demands [1–3]. Meanwhile, efficient energy storage and conversion systems are extremely necessary for the wide application of electronics and electric vehicles [4]. Among various energy technologies, fuel cells have attracted extensive attention due to their high energy conversion rates, abundant fuel resources, and environmental friendliness [5,6]. Fuel cells convert chemical energy into electricity, through redox reactions involving oxygen and fuels [7,8]. The anodic reaction is the oxidation of fuels, while the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) takes place at the cathode [9–11]. From a theoretical viewpoint, fuel cells can provide power output continuously with the sufficient fuel supply. Compared to the fast anodic oxidation, the cathodic ORR involves complex and multistep proton-coupled electron transfer processes, hence its slow kinetics, which in turn determine the performance and cost of the fuel cells [12]. Carbon supported Pt nanoparticles (Pt/C) catalysts have been found efficient in accelerating ORR in fuel cells, and are therefore the representative commercialized catalysts in this category, as the activity and stability of non-noble metal catalysts alone are still far inferior to those of their noble metal counterparts [13]. Nevertheless, its scarce resource and high cost limit the commercial application of Pt-based catalysts. For instance, Toyota Mirai, a new fuel cell vehicle, currently uses approximately 20 g of Pt per vehicle [14], an amount which hinders its scaled-up usage in the fuel cells for transport purposes [15,16]. Consequently, to meet the demand for wider applications of fuel cells, developing highly efficient and durable ORR catalysts is the primary priority. Over the past decade, enormous efforts in research and industrial communities have been devoted to improve the catalytic performance of Pt catalysts [17]. Optimization of morphological structure and regulation of chemical composition are regarded as essential and effective improvement strategies. The former refers to the construction of external morphologies (wire, nanosheet, flower, core-shell, nanoframe and assemblies) to achieve efficient utilization of active sites, electron transmission and mass exchange. The latter is based on the electronic structure, atomic arrangement and component coordination, to change the catalytic adsorption interface, and obtain much better intrinsic activity (disordered and ordered Pt alloys, high-index facets and strain effect). Typical strategies such as near-surface regulation and local coordination optimization are also reported to stimulate catalytic activity by adjusting the adsorption of intermediate products and enhancing the utilization of active sites [18–20]. In this regard, low-dimensional nanostructures, especially one-dimensional (1D) Pt-based catalysts and their assembly architectures have been widely investigated due to their following unique structural advantages in chemical and physical properties. 1D Pt-based catalysts with specific facets exhibit improved intrinsic activity [21–23]. High-index facets usually contain an abundance of unsaturated coordinating atoms and defects that can be used as active sites, which would weaken the absorption of oxygenated intermediates at the catalytic interfaces. Therefore, it is promising for designing 1D Pt-based structures with high-index facets, by controlling the synthesis conditions. Similarly, 1D structures usually possess a high aspect ratio, which endows an advanced capability for electron transfer. Their anisotropic structures show large specific surface areas and the channels provided by nanotubes or the interspace between 1D assemblies may accelerate reaction kinetics through rapid reactant transport and product delivery [24,25]. Finally, these 1D Pt blocks could be employed as structural units to assemble into more diverse superstructures in two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) forms, which provide more possibilities for future development of advanced 1D nanocatalysts [26,27]. The assembly of 1D nanostructures into 2D membranes and 3D networks demonstrates their high porosity, open pore structure and high surface-to-volume ratio [28,29]. Besides, they can form a thin catalyst layer without carbon supports, which is very close to the true state of the electrode [30,31]. The engineering not only promotes the improvement of ORR catalytic performance but also stimulates the application potential of 1D Pt-based catalysts in fuel cells. With the blooming development of nanomaterials and nanotechnologies, the wide development of 1D Pt-based catalysts has been witnessed within the last decade. It is therefore necessary and timely to summarize the exciting achievements and existing challenges, which could stimulate more endeavors to apply 1D Pt nanocatalysts for fuel cells. In this study, we provide a thorough overview of 1D Pt-based nanostructures for ORR catalysis (Scheme 1 ). The ORR mechanism in fuel cells will be briefly introduced, followed by a detailed discussion on synthesis strategies (template-based and template-free strategies). Moreover, a series of regulation strategies (structure regulation and composition optimization) will be highlighted for the production of more efficient 1D Pt-based nanocatalysts. Finally, advantages and limitations of 1D Pt-based nanocatalysts along with some other perspectives will be pointed out. We believe this summarized contribution will be helpful for extensive research towards the rational design of 1D Pt nanostructures for efficient ORR electrocatalysis. 2 Reaction mechanism In the past few years, extensive research progress has been made in the synthesis of non-Pt catalysts for alkaline electrolytes [32]. Nevertheless, fuel cells have a higher power density and a wider range of applications in acidic electrolyte compared to alkaline conditions. This study will therefore focus on the ORR electrocatalysis in acid electrolytes. Typically, oxygen molecules diffuse to the electrode surface through the solution mass transfer process and adsorb onto the reaction sites of catalysts. According to the mass concentration and reaction conditions in the electrolyte, oxygen molecules are evolved into a bunch of oxygenated intermediates adsorbed on the active surface site of catalysts, where an electrocatalytic reduction reaction occurs (O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O) (Fig. 1(a) ) [33]. The exact mechanism for ORR has been long debated and found to most likely follow either one of two pathways. The first is the direct four-electron pathway [34], which is further divided into two possible pathways, namely, the dissociative pathway (O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2O* + 4H+ + 4e− → 2HO* + 2H+ + 2e− → 2H2O) and the associative pathway (O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → HO2* + 3H+ + 3e− → O* + HO* + 3H+ + 3e− → 2HO* + 2H+ + 2e− → 2H2O), where both dominate the oxygen reduction process [35], and have water as their end product. The second reaction mechanism is the continuous two-electron pathway, where H2O2 is generated through a two-electron process, then it is reduced to H2O through another two-electron reaction (O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → HO2* + H+ + e− → H2O2* → 2HO* + 2H+ + 2e− → 2H2O) [36]. Notably, the H2O2 intermediates generated during the two-electron pathway are assumed to destroy the proton exchange membrane and lead to the performance degradation in fuel cells [37]. Consequently, the reduction path for oxygen molecules is expected to be achieved via the four-electron transfer process. Equations from other studies have revealed that oxygen decomposition occurs when the oxygen-containing intermediates (O or OH) adsorb and desorb onto the catalytic surface during electrocatalysis. The adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates on the catalyst surface determines the catalytic activity. Although the effects of subsequent charge transfer, oxygen cleavage and dissociation, and final reduction product distribution and release cannot be ignored, yet the adsorption strength associated with electronic structure can be used as an indicator to bridge microstructure and performance. Extensive investigations have shown a volcano type relationship between oxygenate adsorptions over various electrocatalysts (Fig. 1(b)) [38]. The adsorption of intermediates on the metals which are on the left of “volcanic diagram” (such as Fe, Ni, Co) is too strong and proton transfer is very slow, while the metals on the right of “volcanic diagram” (such as Ag, Au) show the weak adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates on their surfaces, which hinders proton and electron transfer [39,40]. However, the binding energy between the intermediates and Pt is relatively moderate, thus Pt is positioned at the top of the “volcanic diagram” demonstrating high ORR activity. Nevertheless, Pt is not at the summit of the “volcanic diagram”, indicating the possibility to achieve higher activity by modifying Pt catalysts with transition metals while simultaneously reducing the cost of the overall catalyst system (Fig. 1(c)) [41,42]. When the oxygen is adsorbed on the catalytic interface, the 2p-orbital of oxygen is first coupled with the s-orbital of the metal atom, resulting in single resonance, and then the 2p-orbital of oxygen and the narrow d-orbital of the metal have a strong interaction and split into bonding and antibonding orbitals [43]. The binding energy of oxygen-containing intermediates is associated with their electronic structure [44], thus the d-band center and width can be used as descriptors of ORR catalytic activity. As a result, many efforts have been made to optimize the d-band center and adjust the binding energy to achieve an ideal value weaker than that for Pt(111) by 0.2 eV [38], through structural engineering methods such as those involving the core-shell structure, disordered and ordered alloys. It is thus very important to understand and study the relationship between the electronic structure of Pt and the oxygen-containing adsorption energy, which is of great significance in the synthesis and design of high-efficiency ORR catalysts. Usually, structure optimizing and composition tuning are the key considerations for the improvement of the adsorption energy of oxygenated species at the active sites. The construction of specific structures will create more unsaturated coordination atoms and active sites, which evokes the intrinsic activity of the Pt surface [45]. Besides, regulating the composition can also improve the activity of Pt nanocatalysts through a synergy between the geometric and electronic effects [46]. In this regard, Pt nanocatalysts with 1D nanoarchitectures provide promising opportunities in ORRs from their structural advantages and easy-modification characteristics through the introduction of guest metal or non-metal atoms [47]. Furthermore, their high-dimensional superstructures not only expand the spatial dimensions for the accessibility of active sites but also facilitate the diffusion and transport of reactants and products. Numerous forward-looking studies on 1D Pt-based nanostructures in ORR electrocatalysis have been reported. In this review, we summarize the representative synthesis and application in 1D Pt-based nanostructures, which would promote their diverse development and accelerate their practical application in fuel cells. 3 Synthesis strategies At the early stage, large amounts of bulk Pt materials are usually used to investigate their electrochemical properties. To improve the utilization and decrease the cost of the noble Pt, the size reduction is often employed through the preparation of nanosized Pt particles, ca. Pt black and Pt/C [48]. Nevertheless, the dissolution and migration of Pt atoms lead to the loss of electrochemical surface area and the degradation of catalytic performance in the electrochemical process. On the other hand, the carbon support may be severely oxidized and corroded, especially during startup/shutdown and fuel shortage conditions, resulting in the separation and agglomeration of these Pt particles. Therefore, insufficient activity and relative instability of Pt particles still plague the development of fuel cells that demand high power output and long life [49]. With a deep understanding of Pt catalysts in ORR electrochemistry, the research community has developed many effective solutions for Pt nanocrystals. Among these, the synthesis of Pt nanocrystals in 1D morphologies provides a promising solution to improve both activity and stability [50]. The formation of 1D Pt-based nanoarchitectures involves the chemical and physical crystal nucleation process, growth and assembling with or without additional assistance. 1D Pt-based nanostructures are usually produced by either a “template-based” or a “template-free” method, and both approaches have their advantages. The soft-template method has been extensively used in the tailored synthesis of 1D Pt-based nanostructures with a rough surface. Meanwhile, the template-free method, where no specific template or substrate is required, eliminates the extra effort required for the preparation and final removal of templates and offers possibilities for obtaining more complex 1D assemblies with abundant surface characters through one-step synthesis. 3.1 Template-based method Limited by the principle of the lowest overall energy, the growth rate of each crystal facet is continuously adjusted during the crystal growth process, using the anisotropic growth mode [51,52]. Similarly, the synthesis of 1D Pt-based nanostructures with a high aspect ratio is mostly limited by this anisotropic growth. Therefore, an additional template or substrate is necessary to limit the growth in a specific direction [52]. Usually, hard (Fig. 2(a) ) and soft (Fig. 2(b)) templates are used in the preparation of 1D nanostructured Pt catalysts [53,54]. Typical hard templates in the form of nanotubes are usually used for the preparation of 1D Pt-based nanostructures. For example, aluminum oxide templates are extensively employed in the preparation of Pt-based nanotubes by entirely covering the inner or outer pore surfaces, while Pt-based nanowires are obtained when the pore channels are completely filled [55]. Subsequently, these hard templates are removed by post-processing. The outer surfaces or inner channels provide deposition spots and growth space to control the formation of 1D nanotubes or nanowires. Moreover, some of the traits found in the resultant Pt nanostructures are always inherited from the initial template. Thus, the parent template can easily tune the diameter, length, as well as the complex architectures involved. For example, Pt species were electrochemically reduced and deposited into the channels of mesoporous silica [56]. After removing the silica template in HF or NaOH solution, a 3D ordered network composed of Pt nanowires was obtained. When SiO2/Al2O3 is used as the hard template, Pt species are often deposited and confined in the pores. Limited by the diameter and shape of the template channels, the diameters of resultant 1D Pt-based nanostructures are generally thick. In this regard, a series of thin nanowire templates have been developed for the preparation of 1D Pt-based nanowires or nanotubes [57,58]. Generally, the content of Pt deposition and the diameter of parent nanowire template determines the final nanotube or nanowire morphologies. Similarly, it is worth mentioning that these specific nanowire templates can be used as self-sacrificial templates to react with Pt species and achieve alloyed nanowires or nanotubes, whereas SiO2/Al2O3 is only a hard template and does not react with Pt species. For example, Ag nanowires are used as self-sacrificial templates, to synthesize Pt nanotubes and Pt-Pd alloy nanotubes [59]. Moreover, tellurium (Te) nanowires and their assembly are also employed in the preparation of 1D Pt-based catalysts with multi-components of Pt-Te, Pt-Pd-Te, and Pt-Au-Te [60]. Due to the strong surface charge polarization effect, the heterogeneous Pt/Pt-Te catalyst showed enhanced ORR catalytic activity and stability compared with homogeneous Pt-Te and Pt/C [60]. The hard-template approaches have enrichened the morphological evolution of the resultant Pt nanostructures. Nevertheless, their linear 1D structures are usually rigid and lack micro-/macrostrain within the skeleton itself, thus the advantage of (sub)surface content is not fully utilized in the electrochemical reactions, and the subsequent removal of hard templates also involves more complicated procedures. Therefore, soft matter like peptide and DNA chains have emerged as templates for the preparation of 1D Pt-based nanowires [61–63]. For example, ultra-long Pt nanowires were synthesized using insulin amyloid fibrils as a template [64]. These soft templates are easily modified by functional groups, which induce the inaction of Pt species on the surface of templates. For instance, the purine nucleotide can work as an electron donor and interact directly with Pt(II) species via the covalent bond, where Pt(II) is reduced and connected along the DNA strand to obtain 1D Pt-based nanostructures [65]. Pt(II)/DNA was reduced into colloidal Pt/DNA composite which was used as the precursor for Pt nanowires or nanometer electronic devices, with good long-term stability without precipitation (one month) [66]. A series of organic surfactants with a hydrophilic head and hydrophobic chain can form slender micelles, which demonstrates the similarity in diversity with biological templates in the formation of 1D Pt nanostructures. With the restricted reduction of Pt species inside the micelles, nanorods or nanowires are usually obtained. For example, Pt-Fe nanowires/nanorods were synthesized in a mixed solution of oleylamine and octadecene [67]. Oleylamine was self-organized outside the Pt-Fe core to form an elongated reverse micelle structure. By controlling the volume ratio of oleylamine and octadecene, the length of the resultant Pt-Fe catalyst was adjusted from above 200 to 20 nm. Other surfactants like cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) can also be used to form micelles for the synthesis of Pt-based nanowires [68]. In order to obtain 1D nanostructures with richer composition and structure, a general method for synthesizing multimetallic alloys in the presence of oleylamine and CTAB was proposed [69]. The resultant 1D Pt-Ni nanostructures delivered an excellent and stable ORR catalytic activity. The specific and mass activities were 9.2 mA cm−2 and 4.15 A mgPt −1, which are 51.1 and 34.6 times those of commercial Pt/C catalysts, respectively. When the Pt species are restricted to aqueous shells on the outside of the micelle, hollow nanotubes can be obtained. For instance, nonaethylene glycol monododecyl ether (C16EO8) and polyoxyethylene (20) sorbitan monostearate (Tween 60) combined to form mixed surfactant rod-like micelles with a thick aqueous shell [70]. The Pt precursor was restricted and reduced on the thick aqueous shell of the micelle to obtain nanotubes with inner and outer diameters of 3 and 6 nm, respectively. 3.2 Template-free approach Both hard and soft templates are commonly used for synthesizing 1D nanostructures. Hard templates are easier to control, while the soft templates prefer to form longer and more flexible 1D nanostructures. Nevertheless, the removal of templates and organic surfactants are complicated tasks. Typically, high-temperature calcination and acid treating are two common strategies, which are likely to induce surface deformation and composition reorganization for enhanced activity [71,72]. For example, acetic acid-treated 2.5 nm Pt-Fe nanowires and annealed 6.3 nm Pt-Fe nanowires demonstrated higher mass and specific activity than the untreated counterparts [73]. It is worth mentioning that excessive post-processing may cause irreversible shape changes, aggregation, and fusion of Pt particles [52]. Similar to the growth mechanism of carbon nanotubes by chemical vapor deposition, the formation of 1D Pt nanostructures can be achieved by the continuous reduction of Pt species through the tip growth style [51]. For example, Pt nanowires grew directly on the surface of Pt or W gauze by the iron-mediated polyol process (Figs. 3(a) and (b) ), where Pt species were slowly reduced to Pt atoms first, and then nucleated and grew into uniform nanowires on the surface of the Pt or W gauze [74,75]. The active surface of the Pt gauze coated with nanowires was approximately three times larger than that of the Pt gauze alone. In addition, other substrates like Si or polymeric/ceramic particulates can also be used for the growth of Pt nanowires [76,77]. In nature, Pt nanocrystals grow preferentially in an anisotropic way [78], and the subsequent oriented attachment of these nanoparticles is also an excellent choice for the formation of 1D nanowires [79]. We reported a template/substrate-free approach for the synthesis of ultrathin and ultra-long Pt nanowires [28]. A mixed solution of ethylene glycol and N,N′-dimethylformamide was used as the reductant for Pt species, while the emergence of soluble amine protected the assembly of Pt nanoparticles in the 1D direction. This method can be applied in the preparation of multi-element 1D Pt alloys with different stoichiometric ratios, for example, Pt-Pd [28], Pt-Fe [80], and Pt-Au [81]. Typically, the twisted Pt-Fe nanowires (Figs. 3(c) and (d)) showed high ORR activity and durability because of the surface lattice strain and specific facets [80]. The mass activity of Pt24Fe76 was 3.4 A mgPt −1, which was 20 times higher than that of commercial Pt/C catalysts, with an activity loss of less than 2% after 40000 cycles, and less than 30% after 120000 cycles (Fig. 3(e)). The Pt ions are reduced to metallic atoms, then they nucleate and generate nanoparticles which gradually deposit and grow along a specific direction to form 1D structures as the reaction time increases (Figs. 4(a)–(d) ) [28,82]. This oriented attachment process has been verified through the real-time observation of the formation of Pt3Fe nanorods [83]. In the first stage, some nanoparticles are formed (Fig. 4(e)), which interact with each other to form nanoparticle chains through shape-directed nanoparticle attachment (Figs. 4(f) and (g)), resulting in structural relaxation into straight nanorods (Fig. 4(h)). Finally, the short nanorods are connected to each other to form long nanorods or nanowires. The synthesis of 1D Pt-based structures, typically nanorods, nanowires and nanotubes, usually involves templates, substrates, capping agents, surfactants and structural directors to overcome the intrinsic anisotropic growth. Nevertheless, Pt-based nanorods/nanowires can be assembled into 1D or 2D/3D superstructures without assistance from external fields. For example, Pt-Fe nanorods were self-assembled into ordered arrays through solvent evaporation, where some nanorods parallel and some perpendicular to the substrate [84]. In addition, the nanorods or nanowires can also be assembled to form some superstructures under the action of external driving forces (electric field or magnetic field, etc.). Under the action of an external magnetic field, the magnetic Pt-Fe nanorods were directly assembled into 2D hexagonal ordered arrays parallel to the substrate [84]. 4 1D Pt-based nanocatalysts for ORR During the ORR process, the reactant/intermediate adsorption and desorption occur on the surface of the Pt catalyst, accompanied by efficient electron transfer and exchange from the catalyst to the reactant/intermediate. The interaction of oxygenates with Pt catalysts determines their catalytic performance, thus ORR catalysts can be tuned by their physical structure and chemical composition [85]. In nature, the morphologies and exposed facets of 1D Pt nanostructures determine the coordination environment of surface Pt atoms. Consequently, shape control is one of the primary effective solutions to achieve an enhanced catalytic performance [86]. Compared with Pt nanoparticles, the 1D Pt catalysts are inert to dissolution and migration, which inhibits redepositing and Oswald ripening, thereby improving electrochemical stability [87]. In general, the geometric structure regulation of the Pt catalysts can improve activity and stability by increasing the utilization of active sites. However, pure Pt catalysts are easily poisoned by reaction intermediates, causing the active sites to be occupied or blocked. This inherent shortcoming cannot be avoided fully simply by controlling the morphologies or external structures. It is therefore necessary to introduce other metals to further modify the electronic structure and adsorption ability of the catalysts. This alloying treatment can reduce Pt consumption, induce stress/ensemble and synergistic effects, change the electronic structure, optimize the adsorption of Pt-O, reduce the adsorption of toxic intermediates, and lower the reaction energy barrier [87]. Meanwhile, the introduction of guest metals may also bring synergistic upgrades to structure and composition aspects, an effect which is conducive for the design of various 1D Pt-based catalysts with outstanding catalytic performance. 4.1 Physical morphologies 1D Pt-based nanostructures with high aspect ratio, specific surface area and atomic utilization endow excellent opportunities in the ORR process [88,89]. The improvement of catalytic activity can be achieved by increasing the number of active sites and/or enhancing their intrinsic activity. When no other heteroatoms are introduced, constructing 1D structures is an effective strategy to improve the ORR catalytic performance of metal Pt. Nanowires with bent and twisted orientation produce additional strain which further increases the number of active sites and improves intrinsic activity [90]. The representative jagged Pt nanowires (Fig. 5(a) ) were obtained by the electrochemical dealloying of Ni atoms and the rearrangement of Pt atoms in core-shell Pt/NiO nanowires [91]. The resultant jagged Pt nanowires exhibited an ultra-high electrochemically active surface area of 118 m2 gPt −1, specific activity of 11.5 mA cm−2 and mass activity of 13.6 A mgPt −1, which were much higher than those for regular commercial Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 5(b)). The Tafel slope of the jagged Pt nanowires was 51 mV dec−1, much lower than that of commercial Pt/C (74 mV dec−1), indicating the faster ORR kinetics of these nanowires. Reaction molecular dynamics simulations showed that high mechanical strain and low coordination of the surface Pt atoms were the main motive for enhancing the ORR activity of jagged Pt nanowires [91]. Typically, reactive force field (ReaxFF) was applied to a bridge nanocluster model to further find that 14.4% of the surface sites on Pt nanowires were barrier-less during the reaction O* + H2O* → 2OH* (rate determining step) from the atomistic perspective [92]. Abundant concave surface sites pushed the OH bond of H2O* towards the O*, resulting in a significantly decreased energy barrier. Assuming each surface site reacted independently, the activity of jagged Pt nanowires would be 212 times that of Pt (111) at 298.15 K, compared to the expected (50 times greater) experimental value. In addition, 1D Pt nanostructures with porous surface ca. nanotubes have a larger electrochemically active surface area, which exposes more active sites to the reactant and electrolyte [93,94]. Consequently, constructing hollow nanotubes is also an effective strategy to improve catalytic performance. For example, the support-less Pt nanotubes (Fig. 5(c)) showed outstanding durability with an attenuation of electrochemically active surface area of approximately 20% after 1000 cycles, much lower than those for Pt-black (51%) and Pt/C (90%) catalysts (Fig. 5 (d)) [59]. Recently, 2D membranes and 3D networks assembled from Pt nanowires have attracted extensive attention. Compared with 1D nanowires/nanorods, 2D or 3D assemblies based on 1D blocks can achieve the following advantages: high porosity, high flexibility, large surface area and open pore structure, thereby promoting electron transfer and mass exchange for enhanced ORR performance [95–97]. The superstructures of 1D Pt blocks not only inherit their excellent advantages in high activity and stability but also evoke additional functions in promoting the catalytic performance of 1D Pt-based nanocatalysts. For example, a free-standing Pt nanowire membrane (Fig. 5(e)) containing long crystalline Pt nanowires exhibited noteworthy activity and durability due to the efficient exposure of certain crystal facets and fewer surface defect sites, as well as the accelerated electron transfer and gas diffusion by the nanowire network [30]. The electrochemically active surface area of Pt nanowire membranes reduced only by 18% after 3000 cycles, which is much lower than commercial Pt/C (95%) and Pt black (61%) catalysts (Fig. 5(f)). The 3D nanowire network further increases the surface-to-volume ratio and surface exposure, providing accessibility to reactants at the outer and inner surfaces, making them promising ORR catalysts. For instance, mesostructured Pt networks composed of nanowire blocks (Fig. 5(g)) had excellent ORR electrocatalytic performance [98]. After 10000 cycles, the electrochemically active surface area was lost only by 20%, and the half-wave potential was attenuated by only 7 mV (Fig. 5(h)). 4.2 Chemical structures Based on theoretical analysis, Pt element is the best candidate to adsorb the oxygen-containing intermediates, yet it is not at the summit of the famous volcano plot [99]. The distance between atoms can be adjusted by compressive or tensile strain, where 1% strain can downshift the d-band center of Pt by decreasing the binding energy by 0.1 eV, followed by a change in the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing species on the Pt surface, thereby enhancing catalytic performance. Ultrathin, core-shell and twisted 1D nanostructures with abundant strain effect provide conditions for creating a suitable catalytic environment. In addition, the adsorption strength can be optimized through the ensemble effect, where the different surface atomic reaction mechanisms of each component will regulate the electronic environment for the catalytic reaction. Introducing a second metal or multiple metals to form alloys would finely modify the geometric and electronic structures, thus the synergistic effect including strain and ensemble effects would tune the oxygenate adsorption, which is one of the important indicators used to evaluate catalytic performance [100,101]. When Fe, Co or Ni is introduced into Pt, the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates on Pt is reduced, resulting in the increased catalytic activity of Pt [102–104]. Meanwhile, the introduction of Au into Pt improves the stability of Pt, as Au is less reactive than Pt due to its higher oxidation potential [105,106]. Nevertheless, transition metals may be selectively dissolved and leached in the harsh electrochemical ORR conditions, resulting in composition changes, structure collapses and degradation of electronic structure to further weaken the catalytic activity and durability [107]. Therefore, Pt-Ga nanowires (Figs. 6(a) and (b) ) with a strong metal-to-metal interaction were designed [108]. The specific and mass activities of Pt-Ga nanowires were 3.28 mA cm−2 and 1.89 A mgPt −1, which were 12.1 and 10.5 times those of commercial Pt/C. In particular, the mass activity of Pt-Ga nanowires decreased only by 15.8% after 30000 durability cycles compared to 79.6% for commercial Pt/C catalyst (Fig. 6(c)). The H2-O2 fuel cell assembled with Pt-Ga nanowires as the cathode catalyst exhibited a higher peak power density than Pt/C. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrated that the strong p-d hybrid interaction between Ga and Pt synergistically optimized the d-band center of Pt, enhanced its oxidation resistance, and suppressed the leaching of the Ga lattice, thereby significantly improving the ORR performance. The introduction of guest elements into 1D Pt nanostructures can richen the synergistic effect and reduce the usage of Pt in the catalysts [109,110]. However, the differences in solubilities of the metal atoms makes the alloy unstable during the electrochemical ORR processes [33]. Post calcination, acid leaching, and electrochemical treatment are typically employed to remove the unstable component and strengthen the alloy. For example, Fe-Pt-Cu nanorods (Figs. 6(d) and (e)) after acetic acid washing and electrochemical treatment were reported to have greatly enhanced ORR activity and durability [71]. The mass and specific activities were boosted 7 and 5 times more compared to those of commercial Pt nanoparticles, respectively (Fig. 6(f)). The catalytic performance remained the same as the composition and morphology were retained after 5000 cycles. Similar enhanced activity and durability can be found in many 1D ternary Pt-Ni-Co and Pt-Pd-Ni and even in quaternary alloys [111,112]. Though the intrinsic activity of Pt can be increased by the introduction of other transition metals, these disordered alloys are generally characterized by poor durability. Pt-based intermetallic compounds with ordered atomic arrangements are an effective solution strategy. Moreover, Pt-based ordered alloys have higher mixing enthalpies and stronger Pt(5d)-M(3d) interactions, which would improve their corrosion resistance during the electrochemical process [113,114]. In addition, the fixed atomic arrangement is beneficial to stabilizing the catalytic interface so that the entire catalytic reaction can proceed efficiently and steadily [115–118]. For example, a class of hierarchical Pt-Co nanowires (Figs. 6(g) and (h)) with an ordered intermetallic compound structure was synthesized through a wet-chemical approach [103]. The mass activity of hierarchical Pt3Co nanowires still reached 3.41 A mgPt −1, and the morphology, alloy structure and composition did not change after 20000 potential cycles (Fig. 6(i)). Furthermore, the well-defined unit cell structure in ordered alloys is conducive for theoretical calculation modeling, which is convenient for the exploration of the structure-activity relationship. Theoretical investigations have found that the high ORR activity of hierarchical Pt-Co nanowires originated from the threefold hollow sites of the high-index facets and the compressive strain of Pt surface induced by the introduction of the smaller atomic radius Co [103]. Modification in composition by the addition of transition metals could optimize the structure of 1D Pt-based nanocatalysts. The synergistic effect of the component and structure usually achieves a disproportionately greater effect. Typically, after the acid/alkaline and electrochemical treatment, the soluble components of alloyed 1D nanostructures leach out to form the porous and hollow structure, i.e., Pt alloy nanotubes (Fig. 7(a) ) [119]. Both the inner and outer surfaces of the highly open structure could be utilized as active sites, which greatly improves the electrochemically active surface area and catalytic activity (Fig. 7(b)). With advances in materials design and synthesis techniques, more and more 1D Pt-based catalysts with different components and novel structures have been extensively investigated. The introduction of guest metals can adjust the electronic structure of Pt, reduce the d-band center, and improve catalytic activity. The specific nature of 1D Pt-based nanostructures allows for the exploration of high catalytically active surfaces and optimization of the electronic structure of Pt and the adsorption energy for oxygen-containing intermediates, thereby improving catalytic performance. Recently, our group reported corrosion investigations on 1D Pt-Ni alloys during the ORR process [120]. The solid 1D bunched Pt-Ni nanospheres suffered from an immethodical service failure in the structure configuration, as the corrosion of Ni would promote the dissolution of some active Pt during the electrochemical ORR process. We then employed the mild chemical etching method to remove the Ni component and tune the near-surface composition to achieve 1D bunched Pt-Ni nanocages with a Pt-rich shell and Pt-Ni alloy core in the wall (Fig. 7(c)). Compared with the commercial Pt/C catalyst, the half-wave potential of bunched Pt-Ni nanocages was positively shifted by 63 mV (Fig. 7(d)). The mass and specific activities of the resultant bunched Pt-Ni nanocages reached 3.52 A mgPt −1 and 5.16 mA cmPt −2, which were 17 and 14 times greater than those of commercial Pt/C, respectively. A lower Tafel slope of the bunched Pt-Ni nanocages exhibited their improved ORR kinetics. More importantly, the bunched Pt-Ni nanocages exhibited robust stability with merely 1.3% decline in mass activity even after 50000 cycles (Fig. 7(e)). Both the hydrogen-air fuel cell (0.6 V, 1.5 A cm−2) and self-breathing fuel cell (0.6 V, 170 mA cm−2) also displayed a high and stable service performance for the resultant bunched Pt-Ni nanocages (Fig. 7(f)). Moreover, the in-situ synchrotron radiation results revealed a weak, yet stable Pt-O/OH adsorption for the bunched nanocages in the working potential range of 0.54–0.9 V, which explained their high activity and stability. Interestingly, the Pt atoms on the surface of the bunched Pt-Ni nanocages with Pt-skin structure had a higher adsorption strength and overflow barrier under the combined strain and coordination effect, proving that the Pt-Ni alloy catalyst with a Pt-skin structure possessed outstanding structural stability. The catalytic performance of 1D Pt-based catalysts can be optimized through both physical morphology and chemical structure. Another key factor that affects performance is the catalyst support, which not only provides a platform to anchor the catalyst, and improves conductivity and electron transferability, but also delivers additional catalytic activity and durability [121]. At present, the commonly used support is carbon black, but it is prone to oxidation and corrosion at high potentials, which leads to the migration and aggregation of Pt catalysts and a great decrease in catalytic performance. In order to solve the above problems, other carbon materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, carbon cages and carbons derived from metal-organic frameworks have been researched, [122–124]. Compared with graphene, carbon nanotube supports, do not suffer from the problem of agglomeration and accumulation of graphene sheets. The N-doped carbon nanotube frameworks obtained by thermal treatment of ZIF-67 particles exhibited additional ORR activity [125]. After 5000 cycles, their half-wave potential only shifted negatively by 7 mV, and the Tafel slope remained almost unchanged. Remarkably, the integration of 1D Pt-based nanostructures and novel carbon nanotubes has not only relatively advanced catalytic activity and stability, but it has also resulted in broad application prospects within the actual fuel cell. Even if the Pt loading was less than half of that for Pt/C catalysts, the power output of thin-film electrodes composed of Pt nanorods grown on N-doped nanotubes was 0.544 W cm−2, 1.23 times that of Pt/C catalysts [126]. After 3000 accelerated stress testing cycles, its surface area lost only 41% of its activity, a value much lower than that for the commercial Pt/C catalyst (76%) [126]. In addition to the aforementioned carbon supports, transition metal compounds have also been extensively investigated. Although transition metal nitrides have excellent electrical conductivity and corrosion resistance, most of their tests in acidic environments remain at the rotating disk electrode (RDE) level, and they are rarely used for membrane electrode assembly (MEA). However, the H2-air fuel cell with tubular Ti0.8Co0.2N nanosheet assemblies as the cathode catalyst showed a power density of 100 mW cm−2 at an open-circuit voltage of 0.84 V, making it one of the low-cost ORR catalyst candidates [127]. Particularly, Pt nanowires/Ti0.7Ru0.3O2 exhibited outstanding ORR catalytic durability thanks to the ultra-high stability of the Ti0.7Ru0.3O2 support under acidic conditions [128]. After 2000 cycles, its current density was only reduced by 2.2%, which is much lower than both that of the Pt nanowire catalyst supported on carbon and commercial Pt/C catalysts. 5 Conclusion and perspectives Fuel cells have broad application prospects in small power generation equipment and long-life batteries. However, the cathodic ORR is the key reaction in fuel cells, its slow kinetics severely limit the service performance of fuel cells. At present, Pt is considered to be the most promising choice as ORR catalysts [129]. In recent decades, the global research community has contributed a lot in designing and constructing diverse 1D Pt-based nanostructures for efficient ORR, as they have diverse potentials and advantages in regulating composition and structure, which are the fundamental features for improving both catalytic activity and durability, simultaneously. The composition and structure of Pt are primarily determined by the synthesis strategies. Consequently, we focused on their synthesis principles in this review, and the structure optimization and composition regulation are also discussed in detail to obtain advanced 1D Pt-based ORR catalysts (Table 1 ). In the discussion, we will propose future development possibilities for 1D Pt-based catalysts from the perspectives of synthesis strategy, structure optimization, physical characterization, computer simulation, and practical application (Scheme 2 ). This review systematically introduces the representative synthesis methods, as there is still much room for controllable synthesis and assembly of 1D Pt nanostructures. Developing facile methods to realize the controllable synthesis endows diversity in the exploration of 1D Pt nanostructures. To date, few methods have achieved large-scale production, consequently, it takes a lot of effort to realize the transition from laboratory level to commercialization scale. Compared with nanostructure engineering, the alloy strategy is equally beneficial for reducing Pt consumption and richening the structure construction as well as stimulating the synergistic effect from component and structure optimization. For instance, advanced structures such as the Pt-skin surface, high-index facets, and core-shell, hollow, ultrafine structures can be achieved. Recently, high-entropy alloys have attracted extensive attention. In this regard, ternary, quaternary, or even high-entropy alloys with more elementary components would provide some solutions in the 1D Pt-based nanostructures for ORR electrocatalysis. As an important part of the catalytic system, the optimization and upgrade of supports have a profound impact on the catalytic performance. The design and synthesis of supports with excellent conductivity and corrosion resistance is also a key topic. On the other hand, self-supported 2D or 3D superstructures may be one of the important directions towards the development of Pt-based catalysts in the future, as they can avoid the problems of support, corrosion and catalyst particle agglomeration in practical fuel cells. The relationship between structure and performance is still sought to be understood due to the complicated contribution from component and structure in 1D Pt-based nanocatalysts. The identification of active sites and reaction indicators (ca. strain, oxygenate adsorption energy etc.) would help in the prompt screening of Pt-based catalysts for the ORR process. Moreover, the oxidation/dissolution/corrosion, reduction/deposition, and the migration and aggregation of Pt nanocatalysts under harsh electrochemical conditions could be monitored and avoided by effective strategies. Pt-based materials are always facing the challenge of being attacked by oxygenated species when they are adsorbed and desorbed during ORR electrocatalysis. Except for the catalytic behavior and reaction process, in-situ techniques including electron microscopy, synchrotron radiation, and some spectroscopy methods can be used to monitor the dynamic evolution in structure and composition of Pt-based catalysts, which would provide more insight into catalyst degradation and failure [130]. Together with simulations and previously researched data on the Pt catalyst family, future developments in machine learning would promote the screening and designing of efficient 1D Pt nanocatalysts. Recently, a robot synthesis system equipped with artificial intelligence technology has been reported for the continuous synthesis of organic chemicals and medicines [131]. It is believed that screening, design, preparation, and measurement will be completed by artificial intelligence technology, thereby saving manpower, and promoting efficient catalyst development [132]. More importantly, efficient 1D Pt-based catalysts still come with poor practical applications in fuel cells. Except for their design and synthesis, the present measurement is completed on RDE, which is beneficial for the quick evaluation of Pt catalysts. However, their real service in fuel cells is unsuccessful, as it costs time and materials within the fuel cell system. Thus, measurement in single cells or MEAs would be crucial, as these are much closer to the real application environment in fuel cells, and can give an understanding of the service information under working conditions [133]. Last but not least, developing active and robust Pt electrocatalysts is critical to upgrading service while decreasing the cost of fuel cells. Although 1D Pt-based nanostructures have demonstrated excellent ORR performance, they still have a long way to go for large-scale applications in fuel cells. In particular, the 1D nanostructures with high atom utilization can be integrated with a diffusion layer to effectively assemble the catalytic layer. This shows significant strength for the stimulation of the traditional membrane-electrode preparation process and for fuel cell performance. We believe that more endeavors in 1D Pt nanostructures will offer a bright future for the production and application of high-performance fuel cells. Bao Yu Xia is currently a full professor in the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST). He received his Ph.D. degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 2010. He worked at Nanyang Technological University from 2011 to 2016. He has served as an Editorial board member in Chin. J. Catal. since 2020. His research interests focus on nanocatalysts in sustainable energy and environment technologies including fuel cells, batteries and carbon dioxide conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Fuel cells have attracted extensive attention due to their high conversion efficiency and environmental friendliness. However, their wider application is limited by the poor activity and high cost of platinum (Pt), which is widely used as the cathode catalyst to overcome the slow kinetics associated with oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Pt-based composites with one-dimensional (1D) nanoarchitectures demonstrate great advantages towards efficient ORR catalysis. This review focuses on the recent advancements in the design and synthesis of 1D Pt-based ORR catalysts. After introducing the fundamental ORR mechanism and the advanced 1D architectures, their synthesis strategies (template-based and template-free methods) are discoursed. Subsequently, their morphology and structure optimization are highlighted, followed by the superstructure assembly using 1D Pt-based blocks. Finally, the challenges and perspectives on the synthesis innovation, structure design, physical characterization, and theoretical investigations are proposed for 1D Pt-based ORR nanocatalysts. We anticipate this study will inspire more research endeavors on efficient ORR nanocatalysts in fuel cell application.

coredata.dc:title: Rational design and synthesis of one-dimensional platinum-based nanostructures for oxygen-reduction electrocatalysis
